comment_body: Kamil, could you pls explain whats missing in the change thats causing the latest error.

unittest fails since you added extra field to queue struct:

```./saiserializetest >/dev/null
ASSERT STR_EQ FAILED(test_serialize_notifications:1052): is:
{"count":1,"data":[{"queue_id":"oid:0x0","event":"SAI_QUEUE_PFC_DEADLOCK_EVENT_TYPE_DETECTED","app_managed_recovery":false}]}
expected:
{"count":1,"data":[{"queue_id":"oid:0x0","event":"SAI_QUEUE_PFC_DEADLOCK_EVENT_TYPE_DETECTED"}]}
```

take a look at meta/saiserializetest.c at line 1052
@sihuihan88 to review
@kcudnik Could you merge this pull request to SAI-v1.2 branch?
Instead of validonly use condition on attributes where they are mandatory on create
instead sai_bfd_capability_t use 3 attributes readonly on switch, then you dont need to introduce new type on serialize in metadata

In current conditions for tunnel encap and decap mappers only SAI_TUNNEL_MAP_TYPE_OECN_TO_UECN and SAI_TUNNEL_MAP_TYPE_UECN_OECN_TO_OECN mappers can be attached to tunnel. 
Removed condition section from tunnel encap and decap mappers to support attaching all types of mappers.
BTW: Are SAI_TUNNEL_ATTR_UNDERLAY_INTERFACE and SAI_TUNNEL_ATTR_OVERLAY_INTERFACE attributes mandatory on create only on IPINIP and IPINIP_GRE types? If not, need to change condition section in attribute description.
I approved only for code change, but FYI, if you remove those conditions, then those 2 attributes will be **mandatory** every time tunnel will be created

i am not sure we want to make these attributes always mandatory. perhaps then we should remove the mandatory clause and give a default of empty list ? (but then we will miss the check that if user modes are defined, a map must be attached)

@itaibaz If we leave the code as is how the mappers of the types other than ECN related can be attached to the tunnel? We're trying to figure out how to connect bridge-to-vni mappers to the tunnel and looks like with the current definitions we can't do this.
@itaibaz I have pushed changes according to your comment. Could you please review?

BTW, there are other inconsistencies in attributes definitions:
1. Are SAI_TUNNEL_ATTR_UNDERLAY_INTERFACE and SAI_TUNNEL_ATTR_OVERLAY_INTERFACE attributes valid only on IPINIP and IPINIP_GRE types?
```
     * @type sai_object_id_t
     * @flags MANDATORY_ON_CREATE | CREATE_ONLY
     * @objects SAI_OBJECT_TYPE_ROUTER_INTERFACE
     * @condition SAI_TUNNEL_ATTR_TYPE == SAI_TUNNEL_TYPE_IPINIP or SAI_TUNNEL_ATTR_TYPE == SAI_TUNNEL_TYPE_IPINIP_GRE
```
2. SAI_TUNNEL_ATTR_DECAP_TTL_MODE and SAI_TUNNEL_ATTR_DECAP_DSCP_MODE are valid only on IPINIP and IPINIP_GRE types and on encap TTL and DSCP modes don't have such conditions.
@IGordynskyi Yes seems the attribute conditions have not been updated to accommodate the newer tunnel types and other changes which have happened in this file over time.

> @IGordynskyi Yes seems the attribute conditions have not been updated to accommodate the newer tunnel types and other changes which have happened in this file over time.

@karthik-krishnamurthy should that be fixed in scope of this PR?
@kcudnik since this pull request is approved by you and @itaibaz could you please merge it?
Merged
Thanks!
Build triggered. sha1 is merged.
@lguohan @kcudnik Is this planned to merged to 1.2 as well?

@lguohan  -- sorry if i missed any of the discussions that happened around this attribute. 

What is the expectation here : SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_AVAILABLE_ACL_TABLE -- will count the available new entries that can be added for a specific ACL table. 

How do we compute SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_AVAILABLE_ACL_TABLE_GROUP -- it can be tricky. 
Can we clarify that this will only compute the aggregate ACL Table Entries available that are bound to a group?
I reviewed only headers implementation part and it looks good to me

@sihuihan88 😆
test this please
I think the purpose of this condition is that by default, there is only one default 1Q bridge. If this attribute is not provided, the bridge port is going to be part of the default 1Q bridge.
this is to create a bridge port that bridges a 1D bridge and router, so bridge ID is needed. not sure why we need to remove the condition.
I think the bridge id should be a mandatory attribute for all bridge port types. That's the reason why the condition is removed.

@stcheng @lguohan 
The understanding of bridge port is that it associates/connects either
a)  Port to a .1Q bridge               (SAI_BRIDGE_PORT_TYPE_PORT)
b) (Port, VLAN) to a .1D bridge   (SAI_BRIDGE_PORT_TYPE_SUB_PORT) 
c)  RIF to a .1Q bridge                 (SAI_BRIDGE_PORT_TYPE_1Q_ROUTER)
d) RIF to a .1D bridge                  (SAI_BRIDGE_PORT_TYPE_1D_ROUTER)
e) Tunnel to a .1D/.1Q bridge     (SAI_BRIDGE_PORT_TYPE_TUNNEL)

Since in all the types of bridge ports we need bridge id, we thought of removing the condition.

IMO, in case it's a .1Q bridge, we don't need the bridge ID
The reason is, there can only be up to a single instance of .1Q bridge at any given time, so giving the bridge ID is redundant
For .1D bridge, we do need the bridge ID

Indeed looks like there is a problem with the condition, so perhaps it should be fixed to 
SAI_BRIDGE_PORT_ATTR_TYPE == SAI_BRIDGE_PORT_TYPE_SUB_PORT OR
SAI_BRIDGE_PORT_ATTR_TYPE == SAI_BRIDGE_PORT_TYPE_1D_ROUTER OR
SAI_BRIDGE_PORT_ATTR_TYPE == SAI_BRIDGE_PORT_TYPE_TUNNEL
@itaibaz That seems fine as well
@mattyk
@stcheng @lguohan @itaibaz @mattyk  Updated the pull request based on the OCP discussion

Probably not needed since SAI_BUFFER_PROFILE_ATTR_THRESHOLD_MODE is "create_only" and can't change during object life time, and when buffers are inherited then you should not be able to set them anyway since change will not have effect

Now that I look at it, I agree probably this change is not needed
Static threshold value should be mandatory if (mode is static) OR (mode is inherit form pool and pool is static)
The previous version was more relaxed, saying it is mandatory only if mode is static
if we change to mandatory also when mode is inherit, this is actually wrong. because when mode will be inherit, you will need to provide both static and dynamic values

So I think this change shouldn't go in
And with the existing code, you could still pass either static or dynamic value when using mod inherit
please refer to recent change: https://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/pull/672/files
if the value  is also inherited from the pool, then which attribute shall I use to set the pool's threshold value?

While reading through this PR,  one thing I'm not able to get a clear idea, what are the exact packet format for flow report, drop report and queue report?    I could see they will be udp packet,  are the format of switch info/drop reason/que info fields supposed to vary with different vendor?

Probably I missed something, could some example report packets be shared?

@JipanYanga Thanks for the question. My understanding is that reporting format is out of the scope of SAI definition. SAI only defines the control API for network devices, not the data plane packet format. 

The actual reporting format could be different for different vendors and can evolve while SAI remain the same. Here is an example [draft proposal](https://github.com/p4lang/p4-spec/blob/master/applications/telemetry/DRAFT_Telemetry_Report_Format.pdf) of data plane telemetry report format.

@xiaozhou Thanks for the response.  For drop report and queue report,  external server might be able to handle the different report formats from different vendors. But for flow report, if the packet format is not unified, or at least compatible among vendors,  the usage of data path telemetry would be limited.

@JipanYanga Same with drop report and queue report, a flow report is sent from a network device and then consumed by the monitor server. Switches along the routing path of the report packet do not need to parse the telemetry report format, so there is no vendor compatibility issue.

I think you are actually talking about the packet format for in-band telemetry (e.g., INT, iOAM) rather than the report packet format. In-band telemetry does require network devices agree on the same packet format because telemetry information is inserted into the data packet and need to be parsed and modified by all participating network devices. Here are the specification of [INT](https://p4.org/p4-spec/docs/In-band%20Network%20Telemetry%20(INT).pdf) and [iOAM](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-ippm-ioam-data-01). Again, they should not be specified by SAI.

This will generate over 500 attributes for user defined field since range is 0xFF, but probably you don't need so many at all, please let me know if for example 10 or 5 is enough since i would like to limit this attribute generation to minimum if they are not necessary

I would say that 10 is enough 
Thanks

ACL Table gets the UDF Group object id. That is the information about offset and a length (via UDFs from this UDF Group)

Hi @AshokDaparthi / @MELLANOX-zhichenr / @karthik-krishnamurthy ,

I need some clarifications according to these changes.

Q1: As per SAI_PORT_POOL_ATTR_QOS_WRED_PROFILE_ID and  SAI_BUFFER_POOL_ATTR_WRED_PROFILE_ID descriptions, we have some Port threshold and Buffer Pool threshold. Please point where these values could be retrieved.

Q2: What should happen if several PortPool entities with different WREDs are applied on the same Buffer Pool but different Ports? Which Buffer Pool threshold should be configured?

Q3: Similar to Q2 - one Port and several Buffer Pools (if it possible).

Regards,
Oleh

Hi,

We can apply buffer profiles on buffer pool and portpool. Buffering capacity is controlled by buffer profiles.  Next is WRED on pool, WRED thresholds will take from WRED profile. Behavior is if overall buffering on pool exceeds WRED min and MAX applied with SAI_BUFFER_POOL_ATTR_WRED_PROFILE_ID, WRED will kick in and  same with portpool.

Regards
Ashok D

@kcudnik - could you help me decipher the meta error message?  I made some changes given feedback and I made the segmentroute_endpoint_entry style similar to how sairoute or saifdb implements it.  Its erroring in the autogenerated file and I'm not sure how to fix it.

Looks good, just question about prefix _ST_ wht this stand for? And second sai_segmentroute_st object is not referenced anywhere yet should IT be used in some attribute in sai_segmentroute_endpoint_entry?

@kcudnik - ST stands for Source / Transmit.  It used to be called transmit but it was misleading since this table is used for both source and transmit policy application.  and SOURCE_TRANSMIT naming seemed too long, so I abbreviated it.  Its not for the endpoint entry table.  It's used in the separate table.

@kcudnik thanks for the feedback.  Few points:
1. Color is actually an ID, can't be an enum.  IETF spec says color number & DIP to derive the SR policy, thus, I used unit32 
2. Abbreviations are due to comments from sai meeting feedback
3. Since this is proposal, going through a lot of churn due to various offline comments.  Apologize on the overtime since I'm trying to adapt to all the feedback
I added some more pedantic rules about style in headers, can you respin your change to see if your changes passes those checks ?
You are introducin union, please name it to pass check, look for other union examples in saitypes.h

@lguohan , @shihjeff - SAI_PORT_ATTR_REMOTE_SUPPORTED* this is to get the remote port capability, remote port supported/capable and advertised can be different like what we have for port supported and advertised. if you add a new api enum you need to add code to support that anyway, this enum is i think used right now to set loglevel and to get specific api structure, so adding MAX is not helps in this case, on swich handling api_t you add default tag and add log that this value is not supported, same as some would pass _MAX to get api

In this case, if you add new API emum value before SAI_API_MAX, you don't need to change the memory borders.

Adding objec type also make some issues in metadata since currently serialization type describes allowed object types that can be set/get on current attribute, and serialization type determines whether this type is object id or not, in here serialization type will be qos map, but it also will require allowed object types to be present which make some issues in current metadata logic

How do we resolve conflicts if someone uses extensions from more than one provider ?
Don’t we need to allocate vendor specific base enum offsets..

I think an example showing how will the extension headers be defined and included will help.
It seems to me that the enum values can conflict when two vendors define their own enums for different purposes in the same modules.
Also conflicts can occur for module ids, obj ids, API ids etc. at the top level when including extensions from more than one source.

Added usage notes. Note that there are no conflicts between symbols:
- for attribute extensions, if two vendors provide the same functionality (same extended attributes, say PORT_LED), they should use the same extension attribute. 
- module extensions are completely independent, and if two extension modules provide the same functionality (say, MPLS) they are not used at the same time
